speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: SCENE XIV. The same. Another room.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY and EROS

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Eros, thou yet behold'st me?

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Ay, noble lord.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Sometimes we see a cloud that's dragonish;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A vapour sometime like a bear or lion,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A tower'd citadel, a pendent rock,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A forked mountain, or blue promontory

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With trees upon't, that nod unto the world,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And mock our eyes with air: thou hast seen

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: these signs;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: They are black vesper's pageants.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Ay, my lord,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That which is now a horse, even with a thought

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The rack dislimns, and makes it indistinct,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: As water is in water.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: It does, my lord.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Even such a body: here I am Antony:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I made these wars for Egypt: and the queen,--

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which whilst it was mine had annex'd unto't

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A million more, now lost,--she, Eros, has

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Pack'd cards with Caesar, and false-play'd my glory

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Unto an enemy's triumph.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Nay, weep not, gentle Eros; there is left us

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Ourselves to end ourselves.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter MARDIAN

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: O! thy vile lady!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: She has robb'd me of my sword.

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: No, Antony;

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: My mistress loved thee, and her fortunes mingled

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: With thine entirely.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Hence, saucy eunuch; peace!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: She hath betray'd me and shall die the death.

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: Death of one person can be paid but once,

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: And that she has discharged: what thou wouldst do

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: Is done unto thy hand: the last she spake

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: Was 'Antony! most noble Antony!'

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: Then in the midst a tearing groan did break

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: The name of Antony; it was divided

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: Between her heart and lips: she render'd life,

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: Thy name so buried in her.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Dead, then?

speaker: MARDIAN
text_entry: Dead.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Unarm, Eros; the long day's task is done,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And we must sleep.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To MARDIAN

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That thou depart'st hence safe,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Does pay thy labour richly; go.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exit MARDIAN

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Off, pluck off:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The seven-fold shield of Ajax cannot keep

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Heart, once be stronger than thy continent,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Crack thy frail case! Apace, Eros, apace.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: No more a soldier: bruised pieces, go;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: You have been nobly borne. From me awhile.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exit EROS

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I will o'ertake thee, Cleopatra, and

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: All length is torture: since the torch is out,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Lie down, and stray no farther: now all labour

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Mars what it does; yea, very force entangles

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Itself with strength: seal then, and all is done.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Eros!--I come, my queen:--Eros!--Stay for me:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Where souls do couch on flowers, we'll hand in hand,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Dido and her AEneas shall want troops,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And all the haunt be ours. Come, Eros, Eros!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Re-enter EROS

speaker: EROS
text_entry: What would my lord?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Since Cleopatra died,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have lived in such dishonour, that the gods

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Quarter'd the world, and o'er green Neptune's back

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The courage of a woman; less noble mind

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Than she which by her death our Caesar tells

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: 'I am conqueror of myself.' Thou art sworn, Eros,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That, when the exigent should come, which now

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is come indeed, when I should see behind me

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The inevitable prosecution of

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Disgrace and horror, that, on my command,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou then wouldst kill me: do't; the time is come:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou strikest not me, 'tis Caesar thou defeat'st.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Put colour in thy cheek.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: The gods withhold me!

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Though enemy, lost aim, and could not?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Eros,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Wouldst thou be window'd in great Rome and see

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thy master thus with pleach'd arms, bending down

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: His corrigible neck, his face subdued

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To penetrative shame, whilst the wheel'd seat

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: His baseness that ensued?

speaker: EROS
text_entry: I would not see't.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Come, then; for with a wound I must be cured.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Most useful for thy country.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: O, sir, pardon me!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: When I did make thee free, sworest thou not then

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Or thy precedent services are all

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: But accidents unpurposed. Draw, and come.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Turn from me, then, that noble countenance,

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Lo thee!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Turning from him

speaker: EROS
text_entry: My sword is drawn.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Then let it do at once

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The thing why thou hast drawn it.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: My dear master,

speaker: EROS
text_entry: My captain, and my emperor, let me say,

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: 'Tis said, man; and farewell.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Now, Eros.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Why, there then: thus I do escape the sorrow

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Of Antony's death.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Kills himself

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thrice-nobler than myself!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I should, and thou couldst not. My queen and Eros

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have by their brave instruction got upon me

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A nobleness in record: but I will be

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A bridegroom in my death, and run into't

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: As to a lover's bed. Come, then; and, Eros,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thy master dies thy scholar: to do thus

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Falling on his sword

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I learn'd of thee. How! not dead? not dead?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The guard, ho! O, dispatch me!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter DERCETAS and Guard

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: What's the noise?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have done my work in, friends: O, make an end

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of what I have begun.

speaker: Second Guard
text_entry: The star is fall'n.

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: And time is at his period.

speaker: All
text_entry: Alas, and woe!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Let him that loves me strike me dead.

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: Not I.

speaker: Second Guard
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: Third Guard
text_entry: Nor any one.

speaker: Third Guard
text_entry: Exeunt Guard

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings,

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Shall enter me with him.

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Enter DIOMEDES

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Where's Antony?

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: There, Diomed there.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Lives he?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Wilt thou not answer, man?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Exit DERCETAS

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword, and give me

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Sufficing strokes for death.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Most absolute lord,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: When did she send thee?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Now, my lord.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Where is she?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Lock'd in her monument. She had a prophesying fear

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Of what hath come to pass: for when she saw--

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Which never shall be found--you did suspect

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead;

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: But, fearing since how it might work, hath sent

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Me to proclaim the truth; and I am come,

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I dread, too late.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Too late, good Diomed: call my guard, I prithee.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: What, ho, the emperor's guard! The guard, what, ho!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Come, your lord calls!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Enter four or five of the Guard of MARK ANTONY

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: 'Tis the last service that I shall command you.

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: All your true followers out.

speaker: All
text_entry: Most heavy day!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To grace it with your sorrows: bid that welcome

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which comes to punish us, and we punish it

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have led you oft: carry me now, good friends,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And have my thanks for all.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt, bearing MARK ANTONY
